SGS Executive Summary 



Tucson Electric Power Company ("TEP") operates the Springerville Generating Station ("SGS") located near Springerville, Arizona.  SGS uses an ammonia system process at Generating Units 3 and 4 that contains Anhydrous Ammonia in inventories greater than the RMP and PSM threshold quantities of 10,000 lbs. The ammonia system supplies the Selective Catalytic Reduction ("SCR") system with a consistent and reliable source of Anhydrous Ammonia. The ammonia system includes the storage and injection areas. The storage equipment consists of two (2) storage tanks (each having a maximum capacity of 22,840 gallons with an 85% administrative control), rail tank car unloading station, truck unloading station, tank heaters and ammonia supply vaporizer. The injection equipment in the SCR area consists of vapor dilution skids, balancing manifolds, and Ammonia Injection Grid ("AIG").



SGS's Anhydrous Ammonia covered process is subject to the Program 3 prevention program requirements of the Risk Management Plan ("RMP") rule, and aligns with the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management ("PSM") standard (1910.119). SGS takes the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements under 40 CFR Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the Release Prevention Program that are in place at SGS.



1.1. PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

Process Safety Information pertains to highly hazardous chemicals in the process, technology of the process, and equipment in the process. Examples of Process Safety Information include but are not limited to Safety Data Sheets and Piping, and Instrumentation Diagrams. SGS updates its Process Safety Information using a Management of Change ("MOC") process to ensure critical safety information remains accurate for safe operation of the site. Employees can verbally request access for Process Safety Information to the Program Manager.  The Program Manager provides access to approved r

equests during normal working hours.



Process Hazard Analysis 



SGS uses one or more of the following PHA methods, as appropriate, to determine and evaluate the hazards of the process:



-What if

-What If/Checklist

-Hazard and Operability study (HAZOP)

-Failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA)

-Fault tree analysis or

-An appropriate equivalent methodology.



The primary technique that SGS uses to perform hazard evaluations is the What-If/Checklist Methodology, as discussed in 40 CFR Section 68.67.  The purpose of a Process Hazard Analysis ("PHA") is to perform a systematic review of existing and/or proposed processes to identify, evaluate, and control process hazards.



The SGS management team ("team") with expertise in engineering and process operations conduct the PHA. The team is comprised of the SGS Station Manager and his/her direct reports (i.e. Superintendents and select supervisors).  This team reviews and approves recommendations. Once approved, the team assigns the appropriate personnel corrective actions for follow-up. The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as the control measures (prevention and mitigation) currently in place and makes recommendations for additional control measures as appropriate to reduce risks to as low as reasonably practicable. 



SGS tracks action items to closure as outlined in the PHA Policy to ensure it completes follow-up items in a timely manner.  Personnel document completed items and save a copy of the document with the PHA.  SGS revalidates the PHA at least once every five years. The revalidation includes a review of any changes, MOCs, and incidents that have taken place in the process since the last PHA and includes recommendations for the addition of control measures as appropriate. 



1.2. OPERATING PROCEDURES



SGS maintains written operating procedures for each process area that address initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency oper

ations, and normal shutdown and start-up following a turnaround or after an emergency shutdown. These operating procedures are periodically reviewed and revised and are stored electronically on an internal server for employee access.  



1.3. TRAINING



SGS's training program includes formal on-boarding, job-specific training, compliance training, and safety training. SGS provides each employee involved in operating a covered process with initial training and refresher training, including an overview of the process and the hazards and the operating procedures developed for that process. The training supervisor or their designee is responsible for scheduling and coordinating the following training for PSM/RMP affected employees.



1.4. MECHANICAL INTEGRITY



Mechanical Integrity includes all activities required to ensure proper design, construction, and ongoing integrity and reliability of equipment to prevent or minimize incidents for the life of the equipment. SGS's written program details mechanical integrity practices and procedures for inspecting, testing, monitoring, and maintaining process equipment. SGS conducts routine maintenance training for maintenance personnel, and periodically reviews and updates procedures.   



1.5. MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



The MOC program applies to changes that affect the process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and changes to stationary sources that affect a covered process. SGS reviews and approves a proposed modification at conception under the MOC and pre-start up safety review ("PSSR") process prior to implementing the change. SGS tracks the MOC requests and once all the required technical reviews are completed, approves the MOC for change implementation. Training requirements for affected personnel vary depending on the significance of the change. For changes requiring significant updates to procedures or equipment, special training sessions (meeting the training requirements of the company's RMP/PSM programs

) may be necessary for operators, mechanics, and/or contractors. For less significant changes, communicating information about the change and its anticipated effects on operation/maintenance may substitute for training sessions.



1.6. PRE-STARTUP REVIEW



New facilities and modified facilities (when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information) must conduct a PSSR. The PSSR process is used in conjunction with the MOC  process. If the change triggers a PSSR, then approval for startup also satisfies the site's PSSR requirements. The PSSR process requires the appropriate personnel to verify that the change was constructed and installed per the approved design and equipment specifications following the completion of the installation and prior to startup.



1.7. COMPLIANCE AUDITS



SGS audits the RMP/PSM program every three years and verifies that the procedures and practices developed to comply with the RMP Prevention Program and PSM regulations are adequate and followed.  A team knowledgeable in the process, but impartial to the facility or area being audited, conducts compliance audits.  The audit team develops findings and forwards them to SGS Management for resolution.  SGS tracks corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings to closure as outlined in the Compliance Audit Policy, documents the final resolution of each finding and saves the two most recent audit reports on the internal server.  SGS communicates the audit results to relevant personnel and identifies additional training opportunities.   



1.8. INCIDENT INVESTIGATION



SGS conducts an investigation for every incident that results, or could reasonably have resulted, in a release of Ammonia from the Ammonia System according to the Incident Reporting and Investigation Procedure. SGS shares the results of the investigation and lessons learned with appropriate personnel to prevent future recurrence, tracks any corrective actions resu

lting from the incident investigation to closure in accordance with the Incident Investigation Policy, and retains incident Investigation reports for at least five (5) years. To date, SGS has not had an incident that required investigation. 



1.9. EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



SGS encourages participation in Process Safety Management through training and develops cross-functional teams to perform process hazards analyses, incident investigations and compliance audits. SGS makes all new employees aware of the RMP/PSM program as a part of the initial orientation process.  At least one hourly employee or representative of the hourly employee directly involved in the operation or maintenance of the site operations is in all meetings and/or formal discussions concerning RMP/PSM policies and procedures. All files associated with the RMP/PSM program are available by request to the Program Manager.



1.10. SAFE WORK PRACTICES



SGS has safe work practices in place to identify, evaluate and eliminate or mitigate risks associated with high-risk operations to ensure safe and reliable operations. Examples of these include but are not limited to: 

     

     Confined Space Entry  -  the control of the entry, presence, and exit of personnel into confined spaces or other hazardous  work areas; 

     

     Energy Isolation  - a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of hazardous energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance; 

     

     Line Opening/Breaks - procedures for the safe removal of substances that may be hazardous before equipment is opened for inspection and/or maintenance; 

     

     Hot Work Permit - a permit procedure to control activities that may be a source of ignition (i.e. hot work); and 

     

     Security Entry and Control - the controlled entry of personnel into process areas.  



SGS work practices and training of personnel involved in these types of work ensure safe operations and maintenance activities. 



1.11. CONTRACTORS



The Contractor Saf

ety Program includes an initial screening of the contractor and the periodic review of the contractor's safety performance while working at the facility. These requirements are specific to contractors who perform work (e.g. maintenance or repair, turnaround, renovation, or specialty work) on and around the OSHA PSM and EPA RMP-regulated processes. These requirements do not apply to contractors working on non-regulated processes.



1.12. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



SGS has not had any accidents in the past five years.



1.13. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



SGS has not had a significant release of a hazardous substance as defined by the RMP Rule for the covered process. Ammonia from the Ammonia System is the only covered process at SGS. In the event of a release, the facility adheres to its written Emergency Contingency Plan in accordance with OSHA Standards. SGS's Emergency Response Team coordinates with the Apache County Local Emergency Planning Committee to plan and respond to a release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. SGS provides emergency planning and community right-to-know information to the state emergency response commission, local emergency planning committee and local fire department as required by SARA Title III of EPCRA. 



Emergency Response Coordination Activities and Response Exercises



At least once each calendar year, SGS shall meet with the Apache County Local Emergency Planning Committee ("LEPC") as well as coordination with the local emergency response agencies.  At least once each calendar year (prior to December 19, 2024), SGS shall conduct a notification exercise, in which the Control Room Operator shall contact the Apache County Sheriff's Office Dispatch & Communications Center to report an anhydrous ammonia release, and annually thereafter. 



The Control Room Operator shall advise the ACSO Telecommunicator that this is only a test of the notification systems. SGS may perform the notification exercise

as part of the tabletop and field exercises conducted during the emergency response coordination activities. Beginning in 2022, SGS will coordinate and participate in Tabletop and Field Exercises with the internal Emergency Response Team, as well as external Public Safety resources including but not limited to: Springerville Fire Department, Eagar Fire Department, White Mountain Ambulance Service, Apache County Sheriff's Office, St. Johns Emergency Services.



?<    The Notification drill may be exercised as part of the Tabletop and Field Exercises.

?<    Tabletop exercises shall be conducted at least every three years.

?<    Field exercises shall be conducted at least every ten years.



SGS has an exercise program for its emergency response program, which involves facility emergency response personnel, and, as appropriate, emergency response contractors. When planning emergency response field and tabletop exercises, SGS coordinates with local public emergency response officials and invites them to participate in the exercise.



1.14. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 



SGS reviews its safety program and implements revisions as appropriate to enhance safety and promote continuous improvement of operations. SGS conducts periodic audits, inspections and hazard evaluations to assess the maintenance of safe work practices and operations.
